title: I am I am about to file Chapter 7 need some advice?
question: Hello I need some help on a question that I have I'm about to file Chapter 7 BK I have a vehicle that I got in a car accident about 2 years ago at the time of the accident my insurance overlapped and got stuck with the vehicle lender never came for it I requested for them to come and pick up the vehicle various times they told me they do not want it they just want me to pay what I owe on and it would be about $14,000 I have asked for pink slip at lien release I have gotten either once I file bankruptcy can I still keep the vehicle and will they release the pink slip to it for I could keep the vehicle after
answers: Filing bankruptcy does not get rid of the lien the finance company has on the vehicle. The bankruptcy will discharge your personal obligation, i.e. if they repossess the vehicle they can never sue you personally for the deficiency and garnish your wages or execute a bank levy. However, as long as they have the lien they have the right to repossess the vehicle. You could try a 722 redemption which would allow you to keep the vehicle for what it is worth, you can pay them what is owed, or you can just keep driving the vehicle until they repossess it. I hope this helps.

If you want to keep the car for what it is worth, and not one penny more, you will need legal representation to pull off a redemption under 11 USC sec 722. I know of no redemption financing company that will finance you unless you have an attorney representing you. Don't think most experienced bankruptcy attorneys will step in to handle just this matter after you file without an attorney, because a pro se filer is a land mine and anyone with sense will send you packing or charge you double. Hope this perspective helps!

You own the car, they have secured interest. Your options:
1. Continue driving for free as long as you can forever. That is best, just park inside garage if
needed but know it is free driving too as long as possible!
2. Keep car and rent it to a friend as long as you have insurance forever covering you.
3. Tell creditor you will part it out if they don't repo it by a date certain and keep proof you did
notify them with address and ph number to pick up car so you are not sued for conversion. I
would think a week is long enough to pick it up. If not by then, part it out if feasible.
4. Tell creditor you will leave it in their parking lot but then if towed you might be liable for
post-petition fees incurred as our ownership still. But it might make them come repossess it
instead.
5. MOST of the time, the car is worth less than is owed on it. You can offer bank to sell car and
you keep $500 or some $ and they get rest if they agree to it assuming you have no equity. What
if they say yes? If so, find a buyer.
6. You can try an redemption but if the case deadline is passed that is impossible. And costs
money to do one normally with every attorney I know of also pursuant to your contract with that
attorney. And you are paying amount owed or value anyway, whichever is less.
7. See if creditor will agree to send title to junk yard if they send payment directly to Creditor!
That may do it also.
Afterwords, remove all your personal items, notify the state where it is licensed that you are no
longer in possession of it. Why? What if towed or is cited by traffic light type of fine, etc? You
might be liable as owner of the vehicle. Finally, stop the insurance on it. I hope you have a better
understanding of your options now and that I helped. Good luck.

However, other issues and facts can affect your case so I will point them out next for you also. You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an
attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping
everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the
exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523
(Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and
presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so
you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!
Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your
state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but
your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity
thereof!
Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your
options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you
have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply
with your attorney too.
But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a
relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that
relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the
bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so
meet with one no matter what.
Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one
as soon as you can.
You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now
and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

As long as they have their lien on the vehicle, you will not get the pink slip and they have the right to repossess it. If you file BK, you will be personally discharged of the obligation to pay the debt, but their lien will remain. After the BK, if they're not interested in repossessing it, you will be free to drive it until they do (or it dies); but you will not own it and they will not be permitted to ask you for payment.
